events.title: Quadrantid Meteor Shower Peak
events.description: The Quadrantids meteor shower peaks around January 3–4. This is one of the year's earliest major showers.

events.title: Lyrid Meteor Shower Peak
events.description: Lyrids are active around April 22, with rates of ~10–20 meteors per hour under good conditions.

events.title: Eta Aquariid Meteor Shower Peak
events.description: The Eta Aquariids, associated with Halley's Comet, peak around May 5–6. Good for early-morning observing.

events.title: Southern Delta Aquariid Meteor Shower
events.description: Delta Aquariids are active from late July to early August. One of the more southern-hemisphere-friendly showers.

events.title: Perseid Meteor Shower Peak
events.description: The Perseids peak around August 12–13. Under ideal conditions, you could see ~60–100+ meteors per hour.

events.title: Orionid Meteor Shower Peak
events.description: Orionids peak around October 21–22. These are debris from Halley's Comet, and they often produce fast meteors.

events.title: Leonid Meteor Shower Peak
events.description: Leonids peak around November 17–18. Known for bright fireballs in some years.

events.title: Geminid Meteor Shower Peak
events.description: The Geminids are one of the richest annual showers, peaking December 13–14.

events.title: Ursid Meteor Shower Peak
events.description: The Ursids become active and peak around December 21–22 in 2025.

events.title: Jupiter Visible in Late Evening
events.description: Jupiter is well-placed in the night sky for long periods after sunset in mid-2025, according to local sky-chart predictions.

events.title: Saturn Visible Overnight
events.description: Saturn rises early evening and stays visible for many hours, ideal for telescopic and binocular viewing.
